results.title: Dear diary = Caro diario
results.creator_credit: Nanni Moretti, Nella Banfi, Studio Canal, La Sept Cinema, Banfilm and Sacher Film
results.brief_description: Moretti’s intimate and hilarious film diary, which follows the idiosyncratic Italian director’s personal experiences over 18 months, was received rapturously at Cannes where it won the Best Director Award. The film is divided into three chapters: in the first, we follow Moretti on his Vespa through the streets of Rome; in the second, he escapes with a friend to the beautiful Eolian islands; and in the third we see his dealings with conventional and alternative doctors. In Italian with English subtitles.

results.title: Daleks: invasion Earth 2150 A.D. [Widescreen]
results.brief_description: Based on a story from the BBC TV serial “Doctor Who”, Dr. Who and his companions arrive on Earth in the year 2150 AD, only to discover that the planet has been invaded and its population enslaved by the dreaded Daleks. The time travellers assist human resistance groups to foil the Daleks’ plan to mine the Earth’s core.

The time travellers assist human resistance groups to foil the Daleks’ plan to mine the Earth’s core.

results.title: The Bird with the crystal plumage = L'Uccello dalle piume di cristallo
results.creator_credit: Dario Argento, Salvatore Argento, CCC Filmkunst, Speda Spettacoli and Glazier
results.brief_description: An American writer (Tony Musante) working in Italy witnesses an attempted murder when passing an art gallery one night. The attacker escapes making the writer the key witness and potentially, the next victim. Loosely based on a novel by Brian Edgar Wallace, Argento’s first feature helped established the Italian filmmakers reputation as the master of the Gaillo genre (Giallo meaning yellow, the colour of the cheap and lurid horror/thriller paperback novels sold in Italy). ‘The bird with the crystal plumage’s‘ stylish and violent set pieces (enhanced by Vitorrio Storaro’s fluid cinematography and Ennio Morricone’s unnerving score) had Argento dubbed in his home country as the Italian Hitchcock. The comparisons don’t end there however, as both directors also share a taste for sly black humour which Argento displays through the array of oddball characters that populate the film, including a demented artist who eats cats and a pimp with a neurotic streak. Cast also includes Suzy Kendall, Enrico Maria Salerno, Eva Renzi, Reggie Nalder and Mario Adorf. See also ‘Deep red’ (1975), ‘Suspiria’ (1977) and ‘Trauma’ (1993).

results.title: Nostalgia = Nostalghia
results.creator_credit: Andrei Tarkovsky, Francesco Casati, Sovin Film, Radiotelevisione Italiana and Opera Film Produzione
results.brief_description: This is Tarkovsky’s haunting first film made outside of Russia. The story explores the melancholy of the expatriate through the eyes of the film’s protagonist, Gorchakov, a Russian poet researching in Italy. Arriving at a Tuscan village spa with Eugenia, his beautiful Italian interpreter, Gorchakov is visited by memories of Russia and of his wife and children, and encounters the local mystic, who sets him a challenging task. The film is filled with mysterious and extraordinary images, culminating in the final scene where all the film’s images coalesce into a miraculous whole. As in all Tarkovsky films, nature and the elements of fire and water, music, painting and poetry, and the contrast of black and white and colour photography, all play a major role. In Italian with English subtitles.

results.title: Last stand at Saber River
results.creator_credit: Dick Lowry, Steven Brandman, Thomas Kane, Mary Ann Braubach, Turner Entertainment and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: An embittered Confederate soldier returns to his Arizona homestead after the end of the Civil War, only to find it occupied by pioneers sympathetic to the Union war effort. Desperate to rebuild the life he once knew, he is forced to re-consider his loyalties and join forces with his Union adversary to make a last stand for the one thing left worth fighting for - his family.

results.title: Accused
results.creator_credit: Thornton Freeland, Douglas Fairbanks, Marcel Hellman and Criterion Film Productions
results.brief_description: A British melodrama set around a Paris dance troupe and the main performers, Tony (Douglas Fairbanks Jr) and Gaby (Dolores Del Rio) Seymour. When dancer Yvette Delange (Florence Desmond) begins to direct her attentions to the somewhat unwilling Tony, a quarrel ensues between Yvette and Gaby. The sudden death by stabbing of Yvette causes suspicion to fall on Gaby and it is only when the trial takes place, the true identity of the murderer is unmasked. Cast also includes Basil Sydney, Googie Withers, Cecil Humphreys.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Thornton Freeland, Douglas Fairbanks, Marcel Hellman and Criterion Film Productions

results.title: Nasty love = L'Amore molesto
results.creator_credit: Mario Martone, Kermit Smith, Andrea Occhipinti, Angelo Curti, Lucky Red and Teatri Uniti
results.brief_description: A woman goes to investigate her mother’s apparent suicide and ends up having to face the grim reality of her past. Amalia, the sixty-something mother of Delia, is found dead on the beach, when she should have been on her way to visit Delia in Bologna. Delia, wanting to know why her mother killed herself, journeys back to Naples to discover the truth. She encounters her mother’s supposed lover and his son, as well as her estranged father. As she continues to explore, she must face the fact that her relationship with her mother was based on jealousy and disgust as much as it was on love. She must also face up to a terrible lie she told as a child, one that questioned her mother’s fidelity and ruined the lives of everyone around her. In Italian with English subtitles. Cast includes Anna Bonaiuto, Angela Luce, Gianni Cajafa and Giovanni Viglietti.

results.title: The Legend of the holy drinker
results.creator_credit: Ermanno Olmi, Vittorio Cecchi Gori, Mario Cecchi Gori, Vincenzo de Leo, Roberta Cicutto, Aura Film, Tiger Cinematografica and Cecchi Gori Group
results.brief_description: In this award winning Italian film based on the novel by Joseph Roth, Rutger Hauer plays Andreas, an ex-miner jailed for an accidental murder. Released from prison, he is living the life of an alcoholic derelict, under the bridges of Paris until he comes into contact with a stranger, who gives him 200 francs. Andreas is confident of finding work and insists that the money should be a loan only. The stranger asks that he repay the debt to the local parish priest, as soon as he is in a position to do so. Despite Andreas’ good intentions, he is continually caught up with events or old acquaintances that part him from his money, yet strangely, the 200 francs keeps reappearing back in his wallet. Cast also includes Anthony Quayle, Sandrine Dumas, Sophie Segalen and Dominique Pinon.

results.title: For a few dollars more = Per Qualche dollari in piu [Widescreen] (S)
results.creator_credit: Sergio Leone, Alberto Grimaldi, Constantin Film, Arturo Gonzales and Produzioni Europee Associati
results.brief_description: This follow-up to Sergio Leone’s “A Fistful of Dollars” brings back Clint Eastwood as the serape-clad, cigar-chewing Man With No Name. Engaged in an ongoing battle with bounty hunter Col. Douglas Mortimer, Eastwood joins forces with his enemy to capture the homicidal bandit El Indio. Musical score by Ennio Morricone. Cast includes Clint Eastwood, Lee Van Cleef, Gian Marian Volonte and Klaus Kinski.

results.title: Umberto D
results.creator_credit: Vittorio De Sica, Nino Misiano and DEAR Film
results.brief_description: Italian directors of the post-WWII generation, responding to the calamity of facism, to the widespread poverty in both the cities and countryside, and by necessity needing to film inexpensively and to be unencumbered by studio costs, developed a radical realist cinematic aesthetics: neo-realism. Vittorio De Sica became justly famous for his groundbreaking “The Bicycle Thieves”, utilising street locations and performances by non-actors, but it is his unsentimental “Umberto D” that now stands up as the most important film of the Italian neo-realist period. Umberto is a retired civil servant who finds himself unwanted and ignored now that his working days are over. Only his dog gives him affection; humans treat him as already dead, an old man to be shoved aside if they even see him at all. Almost documentary-like in its observation of Umberto (played with sustained brilliance by Carlo Battisti), the film quickly envelops us in the old man’s daily struggles and we find ourselves completely mesmerised by his story, we find ourselves identifying with this tale of a most ordinary “unremarkable” man. As Umberto faces his aching loneliness, and death seemingly becomes his only salvation, we as viewers have to confront our own immersion in the sterility and brutality of our industrialised urban world. The great critic Pauline Kael argued that “Umberto D” is one of those rare films that changes the viewer, that on once seeing the film you can never view the world in the same way again. Critic George Kaufman called it one of “the greatest halfdozen films ever made”. In Italian with English subtitles.
